dimensions.name: weekend_work_intensity
dimensions.description: Amount of work-related browsing activity on weekends (Saturday and Sunday) - the behavior we want to reduce
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event on Saturday or Sunday: count 1 if work-related, 0 otherwise. Work-related includes: technical programming searches, cryptography/security topics, professional documentation (GitHub, StackOverflow, Arch Wiki), tech news (Hacker News), API/library lookups, professional software research.

dimensions.name: weekday_work_volume
dimensions.description: Total work-related browsing activity on weekdays (Monday-Friday)
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event Monday-Friday: count 1 if work-related, 0 otherwise. Work-related includes: technical searches (Haskell, programming, type systems), security/cryptography (PUFs, consensus algorithms, AES), tech news (Hacker News, Phoronix), documentation sites, academic papers, professional tools.

dimensions.name: weekday_leisure_volume
dimensions.description: Leisure and personal browsing activity on weekdays - indicates work-life balance
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event Monday-Friday: count 1 if leisure-related, 0 otherwise. Leisure includes: music (artists, songs, concerts), entertainment, travel planning, food/restaurants, social media, personal shopping, podcasts, general interest (history, geography), personal health tracking.

dimensions.name: late_evening_work
dimensions.description: Work activity occurring after 8pm - indicates boundary blurring between work and rest time
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event with timestamp 20:00-23:59: count 1 if work-related (same criteria as weekday_work_volume), 0 otherwise.

dimensions.name: night_activity
dimensions.description: Any browsing activity between midnight and 5am - indicates sleep disruption or shifted schedule
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event: flag 1 if timestamp is between 00:00 and 04:59, flag 0 otherwise.

dimensions.name: technical_research_intensity
dimensions.description: Density of deep technical browsing - captures intellectual engagement that may spill into weekends
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event: count 1 if deep technical content (programming language theory, type systems, monads/functors, cryptography concepts like PUFs or key exchange, academic papers, Wikipedia on technical subjects, specialized documentation), count 0 for surface-level content or general tech news.

dimensions.name: stress_wellbeing_signal
dimensions.description: Searches related to mental health, stress, sleep, or self-medication - signals potential burnout
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event: flag 1 if related to depression/anxiety treatments, mental health resources, sleep problems, stress management, wellness tracking devices (Oura, Fitbit), or burnout symptoms. Flag 0 otherwise.

dimensions.name: vacation_travel_mode
dimensions.description: Active travel or vacation period - external context that should reduce work tendency
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event: flag 1 if indicates active travel (restaurant/activity searches in vacation destinations, weather for travel locations like 'meteo siracusa', tourist attractions, travel logistics, accommodation lookups). Flag 0 otherwise.

dimensions.name: last_activity_hour
dimensions.description: Hour of final browsing activity each day - late cessation indicates poor sleep opportunity
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event: record the hour of timestamp. Use 24-hour scale extended for post-midnight (1am=25, 2am=26, etc.) to preserve ordering of late-night activity.

dimensions.name: first_activity_hour
dimensions.description: Hour of first browsing activity each day - indicates wake time and morning routine
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each browsing event: record the hour of timestamp (0-23 scale). For pre-5am activity, record actual hour to detect overnight sessions.

dimensions.name: browsing_category
dimensions.description: Topic category of browsing - aggregated diversity indicates scattered vs focused attention
dimensions.how_to_measure: Classify each browsing event into exactly one category: 'programming', 'security_crypto', 'travel', 'food', 'music', 'health', 'news', 'shopping', 'social', 'science', 'history', 'entertainment', 'other'.

dimensions.name: work_engagement_momentum
dimensions.description: Latent weekly state representing accumulated pull toward work activities

dimensions.name: baseline_workaholic_tendency
dimensions.description: Stable individual tendency toward overwork - person-level trait

edges.description: High weekday work volume indicates demanding periods that spill into weekends
More weekday leisure indicates better boundaries, reducing weekend work
Habitual late evening work indicates blurred boundaries that extend to weekends
Night owl patterns indicate disrupted rhythms and poor boundaries
Deep technical engagement creates cognitive momentum that pulls you back on weekends
Stress drives compensatory overwork or indicates burnout requiring catch-up
Being on vacation forces disconnection, reducing weekend work
Later daily cessation indicates poor boundaries that extend to weekends
Earlier wake times may indicate structured routine protecting weekends, or higher pressure
Higher category diversity indicates scattered attention, potentially reducing deep work spillover
Later bedtimes lead to fatigue and reduced next-day productivity
Chronically late bedtimes shift schedule, normalizing late work the next day
Night-time browsing directly extends last activity hour
Working late pushes bedtime later, leading to post-midnight browsing
Working late directly increases last activity hour
Late bedtime leads to sleeping in the next morning
High sustained workload creates stress and prompts wellness searches
Stress leads to anxiety-driven extended work hours
Absorption in engaging problems causes losing track of time
More daytime breaks may require catching up in evening
Higher category diversity includes more leisure topics
Deep technical focus reduces category diversity (stays in fewer categories)
Stress and anxiety keep you up later
Being on vacation naturally reduces work browsing
Vacation increases leisure browsing
Accumulated weekly engagement predicts weekend work propensity
Deep dive episodes build engagement momentum
Higher weekday work feeds into engagement momentum
Stable trait influences how quickly engagement builds
Workaholic tendency manifests as regular late evening work
